column1: A fundamental fact is to be observed in the economy of the young nation: the people were raising far more tobacco and grain and were extracting far more of other products than they could possibly use themselves; for the surplus they must find markets. They had
column3: to rely upon the outside world for a great part of their manufactured goods
column4: especially for those of the higher grade. In other words
column5: from the economic point of view
column6: the United States remained in the former colonial stage of industrial dependence
column7: which was aggravated rather than alleviated by the separation from Great Britain. During the colonial period
column8: Americans had carried on a large amount of this external trade by means of their own vessels. The British Navigation Acts required the transportation of goods in British vessels
column9: manned by crews of British sailors
column10: and specified certain commodities which could be shipped to Great Britain only.
